geoclaw.data module¶

geoclaw.dtopotools module¶

geoclaw.etopotools module¶

Tools to download etopo topography/bathymetry data from NCEI (formerly NGDC). See http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/global/global.html

Note the new etopo1_download_nc is better to use than etopo1_download.

geoclaw.etopotools.etopo1_download(xlimits, ylimits, dx=0.0166666666667, dy=None, output_dir='.', file_name=None, force=False, verbose=True, return_topo=False)[source]¶

Create a url to download etopo1 topography from NCEI and save as a topo_type 3 file. Uses the database described at

http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/global/global.html
Inputs:

  • xlimits: tuple (x1, x2) limits in longitude Must either have -180 <= x1 < x2 <= 180

    or 180 <= x1 < x2 <= 360 or -360 <= x1 < x2 <= -180

    To download topo for a region spanning longitude 180, you must download two separate files, one on each side.

  • ylimits: tuple (y1, y2) limits in latitude Must have -90 <= y1 < y2 <= 90.

  • dx: resolution in x, default is 1./60. degree = 1 arcminute.

  • dy: resolution in y, default is dy = dx.

  • output_dir: directory to store file, default is ‘.’

  • file_name: name of file, default is constructed from xlimits,ylimits

  • force: if True, download even if the file already exists.

  • verbose: if True, print info from clawpack.clawutil.data.get_remote_file

Note: New NGDC format gives cell-registered values, so shift the values xllcorner and yllcorner to the specified corner.

To do: Check whether it is possible to specify grid-registered values as implied at http://www.ngdc.noaa.gov/mgg/global/global.html

The nodata_value line expected by GeoClaw is now missing, so add this in too.

geoclaw.fgmax_tools module¶

geoclaw.geoplot module¶

geoclaw.kmltools module¶

kmltools module: $CLAW/geoclaw/src/python/geoclaw/kmltools.py

Tools to make kml files to overlay on Google Earth. Note that color is in KML format, BGR with 2 hex digits for each, e.g.

FF0000 is blue, 00FF00 is green, 0000FF is red, 00FF00 is yellow.

Actually it’s an 8 hex digit number, where the first two digits are transparency, but in this module these default to ‘FF’ (but you can specify the full 8 digits if you want it transparent).

Functions:
  • deg2dms - convert decimal degrees to (degrees, minutes, seconds)
  • regions2kml - create a kml outline for each regions specified in setrun
  • box2kml - create a kml outline from a rectangular box
  • quad2kml - create a kml outline for an arbitrary quadrilateral
  • poly2kml - create a kml outline for an arbitrary polygon
  • line2kml - create a kml line connecting 2 points
  • gauges2kml - create a kml marker for each gauge specified in setrun
  • kml_header - used internally
  • kml_footer - used internally
  • kml_region - used internally
  • kml_gauge - used internally
  • strip_archive_extensions - strip off things like .tar or .gz
geoclaw.kmltools.box2kml(xy, fname=None, name='box', color='FF0000', width=3, verbose=True)[source]¶

Make a KML box with default color blue.

Inputs:
  • xy a tuple ((x1,x2),(y1,y2)) (preferred)
    or (x1,x2,y1,y2) (for backward compatibility)
  • fname (str) name of resulting kml file
  • name (str) name to appear in box on Google Earth
  • color (str) Color in format aabbggrr
  • width (str) line width
  • verbose (bool) - If True, print out info
geoclaw.kmltools.deg2dms(dy)[source]¶

Convert decimal degrees to tuple (degrees, minutes, seconds)

geoclaw.kmltools.dtopo2kml(dtopo_file_name, dtopo_type, color='8888FF')[source]¶

Create a kml file putting a box around the region covered by a dtopofile. Color is pink by default.

geoclaw.kmltools.f2s(x, num_digits=6)[source]¶

Convert float to string in fixed point notation with at most num_digits digits of precision and trailing zeros removed, for printing nicely in kml description boxes.

geoclaw.kmltools.gauges2kml(rundata=None, fname='gauges.kml', verbose=True)[source]¶

Create a KML marker for each gauge specified for a GeoClaw run.

Inputs:

  • rundata - an object of class ClawRunData or None

    If rundata==None, try to create based on executing function setrun from the setrun.py file in the current directory.

  • fname (str) - resulting kml file.

  • verbose (bool) - If True, print out info about each region found
Example:
>>> from clawpack.geoclaw import kmltools
>>> kmltools.gauges2kml()

is equivalent to:

>>> from clawpack.geoclaw import kmltools
>>> from setrun import setrun
>>> rundata = setrun()
>>> kmltools.gauges2kml(rundata)

By default this creates a file named gauges.kml that can be opened in Google Earth.

geoclaw.kmltools.kml_footer()[source]¶
geoclaw.kmltools.kml_gauge(mapping)[source]¶
geoclaw.kmltools.kml_header(name='GeoClaw kml file')[source]¶
geoclaw.kmltools.kml_line(mapping)[source]¶
geoclaw.kmltools.kml_region(mapping, vertex_text=None)[source]¶
geoclaw.kmltools.kml_timespan(t1, t2, event_time=None, tz=None, tscale=1)[source]¶

Create time strings necessary for sliders in Google Earth. The time span will cover time [t1,t2], with the start of the event given by event_time.

[t1,t2] : time span,

event_time : Start of event in UTC : [Y,M,D,H,M,S], e.g. [2010,2,27,3,34,0] tz : time zone offset to UTC. e.g. +3 for Chile; -9 for Japan.

Time span element looks like

<TimeSpan>
  <begin>2010-02-27T06:34:00+03:00</begin>
  <end>2010-02-27T07:04:00+03:00</end>
</TimeSpan>

As for how well this handles Daylight Savings time, here is what the documentation on the Python ‘time’ module has to say :

“DST is Daylight Saving Time, an adjustment of the timezone by (usually) one hour during part of the year. DST rules are magic (determined by local law) and can change from year to year. The C library has a table containing the local rules (often it is read from a system file for flexibility) and is the only source of True Wisdom in this respect.”

geoclaw.kmltools.line2kml(xy, fname='line.kml', name='line', color='00FFFF', width=3, verbose=True)[source]¶

Make a KML line with default color yellow.

Inputs:
  • xy a tuple ((x1,x2),(y1,y2)) (preferred)
    or (x1,x2,y1,y2) (for backward compatibility)
  • fname (str) name of resulting kml file
  • name (str) name to appear on line on Google Earth
  • color (str) Color in format aabbggrr
  • width (str) line width
  • verbose (bool) - If True, print out info
geoclaw.kmltools.make_input_data_kmls(rundata)[source]¶

Produce kml files for the computational domain, all gauges and regions specified, and all topo and dtopo files specified in rundata. This can be used, e.g. by adding the lines

from clawpack.geoclaw import kmltools kmltools.make_input_data_kmls(rundata)

to the end of a setrun.py file so that make data will generate all kml files in addition to the *.data files.

geoclaw.kmltools.poly2kml(xy, fname=None, name='poly', color='00FF00', width=3, verbose=True)[source]¶

Make a KML polygon with default color blue.

Inputs:
  • xy a tuple (x,y) where x and y are lists of vertices
  • fname (str) name of resulting kml file
  • name (str) name to appear in box on Google Earth
  • color (str) Color in format aabbggrr
  • width (str) line width
  • verbose (bool) - If True, print out info
geoclaw.kmltools.quad2kml(xy, fname=None, name='quad', color='FF0000', width=3, verbose=True)[source]¶

Make a KML quadrilateral with default color blue.

Inputs:
  • xy a tuple ((x1,x2,x3,x4),(y1,y2,y3,y4)) (preferred)
    or (x1,x2,y1,y2,x3,y3,x4,y4) (for backward compatibility)
  • fname (str) name of resulting kml file
  • name (str) name to appear in box on Google Earth
  • color (str) Color in format aabbggrr
  • width (str) line width
  • verbose (bool) - If True, print out info
geoclaw.kmltools.regions2kml(rundata=None, fname='regions.kml', verbose=True, combined=True)[source]¶

Create a KML box for each AMR region specified for a GeoClaw run.

Inputs:

  • rundata - an object of class ClawRunData or None

    If rundata==None, try to create based on executing function setrun from the setrun.py file in the current directory.

  • fname (str) - resulting kml file.

  • verbose (bool) - If True, print out info about each region found

  • combined (bool) - If True, combine into single kml file with name given by fname. This is the default. If False, fname is ignored and individual files are created for each region with names are Domain.kml, Region00.kml, etc. These will show up separately in GoogleEarth so they can be turned on or off individually.

First create a box for the entire domain (in red) and then a box for each region (in white).

Example:
>>> from clawpack.geoclaw import kmltools
>>> kmltools.regions2kml()

is equivalent to:

>>> from clawpack.geoclaw import kmltools
>>> from setrun import setrun
>>> rundata = setrun()
>>> kmltools.regions2kml(rundata)

By default this creates a file named regions.kml that can be opened in Google Earth.

geoclaw.kmltools.topo2kml(topo_file_name, topo_type, color='00FF00')[source]¶

Create a kml file putting a box around the region covered by a topofile. Color is green by default.

geoclaw.most2geoclaw module¶

Module for converting MOST data and output to GeoClaw format.

This is Work In Progress – this module should be improved to use newer topotools.

geoclaw.most2geoclaw.get_comMIT_topo(x1, x2, y1, y2, dx='1m', fname='most_topo.most')[source]¶
Get a topo file from the comMIT Bathymetry server, see
http://sift.pmel.noaa.gov/ComMIT/bathymetry_help.html
Inputs:

  • x1, x2 (floats) extent of longitude (between 0 and 360)

  • y1, y2 (floats) extent of latitude (between -90 and 90))

  • dx (float or str) cellsize in decimal degrees,

    or string such as ‘1m’, ’30s’ for arcminutes or arcseconds.

    Note that etopo1 bathymetry is used to construct this file and then linear interpolation is used if the resolution requested is finer than 1 minute. But onshore topography comes from a different database and may be finer.

  • fname (str) File name to save as.

The result is in MOST format. You can convert to GeoClaw form using most2tt3, e.g.

>>> most2geoclaw.most2tt3('most_topo.most')

But note that this seems to create a file with topo_type == -3.

Retrieving seems to only work for some values of x1,x2,y1,y2 and not others for reasons not yet understood!

geoclaw.most2geoclaw.most2fortq(fnameprefix)[source]¶

Converts MOST output files to fort.q files.

geoclaw.most2geoclaw.most2fortt(fnameprefix)[source]¶

Converts MOST output files to fort.t files.

geoclaw.most2geoclaw.most2tt3(fname, fname2=None)[source]¶

Converts MOST topo file to tt3 format.

geoclaw.okada module¶

okada¶

This version of the Okada routines is deprecated but is being kept around to test geoclaw/examples/tsunami/chile2010 Going forward, dtopotools.okadamap should be used instead. ========================================================

python module for getting Okada maps.

Okada model is a mapping from several fault parameters to a surface deformation. See Okada 1985, or Okada 1992, Bull. Seism. Soc. Am.

some routines adapted from fortran routines written by Xiaoming Wang.

geoclaw.okada.builddeffile(okadaparamfile, faultparamfile, outfile)[source]¶
geoclaw.okada.builddynamicdeffile(okadaparamfile, faultparamfile, outfile, t0=0.0, tend=1.0, nt=2)[source]¶
geoclaw.okada.dip_slip(x1, x2, x3, y1, y2, dp, dd)[source]¶

!…..Based on Okada’s paper (1985) !…..Added by Xiaoming Wang !———————————————————————–

geoclaw.okada.filtermask(dZ, faultparams)[source]¶

borrowed from code written by Xiaoming Wang and Tom Logan at ARSC

!…..Filter the deformation using a circular mask centered !…..at the epicenter using a calculated radius !…..Removes small numerical artifacts away from the epicenter

geoclaw.okada.getfaultparams(infile)[source]¶

obtain params from a file that specify a fault grid from infile params are xlower,ylower,dx,dy,mx,my, OR xlower,ylower,xupper,yupper,mx,my

file format:
parameter names and values should appear on the same single line seperated by a space
geoclaw.okada.getokadaparams(infile)[source]¶

obtain parameters necessary for okada map from config file: infile

file format: parameter names and values should appear on the same single line seperated by a space
geoclaw.okada.okadamap(okadaparams, X, Y)[source]¶

create displacement matrix dZ for a surface displacement over gridded region defined by X,Y, vectors of length nx,ny given okadaparams

geoclaw.okada.strike_slip(x1, x2, x3, y1, y2, dp, dd)[source]¶

!…..Used for Okada’s model !.. ..Methods from Yoshimitsu Okada (1985) !———————————————————————–
